definition: to burn joss paper/(fig.) to flush money down the toilet
to burn/to cook/to stew/to bake/to roast/to heat/to boil (tea, water etc)/fever/to run a temperature/(coll.) to let things go to one's head
coin/money/CL:筆|笔[bi3]/unit of weight, one tenth of a tael 兩|两[liang3]

sentences.english: But that growth will cost money.
I just knew that our sales sucked wind and we were burning through tons of cash.
sentences.chinese: 我只知道公司一边在大量烧钱而另一边却在喝西北风。

sentences.english: Tourists come to New York just to blow money.
sentences.chinese: 游客来纽约就是烧钱的。

sentences.english: Ziheng exclamation film is burning money.
sentences.chinese: 子恒感叹影视圈就是烧钱的。

sentences.english: Many have argued that laptops in a classroom are nothing but splurges.
sentences.chinese: 很多人认为教室里面放笔记本电脑只不过是烧钱。

sentences.english: Q master ordering the dead, something burn, all right burning paper.
sentences.chinese: 夲Q主人已死，有事烧钱，没事烧纸。

sentences.english: As I said before, Soldiers literally need to burn money to train themselves.
sentences.chinese: 像我之前说的，军人需要烧钱去训练自己。

sentences.english: Is natural gas about to explode, or will it just burn your money?
sentences.chinese: 天然气价格将爆发，亦或只是烧钱？

definition: rushing to stake one's claim in new markets
to play yabao (a gambling game)/(fig.) to gamble on/to take one's chance/to try one's luck
income does not cover expenditure/unable to make ends meet
to throw into/to put into/to throw oneself into/to participate in/to invest in/absorbed/engrossed
a one-off, short-sighted deal/a one-shot, all-out attempt
to feel strongly about/to be fond of/obsession/deep commitment
